Projects

Projects (2)
Materials to the Orchid flora of Colombia. Vol. 1.
Project
The study of the orchid flora of Colombia is based on the herbarium materials and field expeditions carried by Szlachetko in 2010-2013 and and Kolanowska in 2009-2014. In the present work the total number of revised specimens was about 30,000 (Pleurothallidinae and Epidendrum excluding). They were either borrowed or examined in the following institutions AAU, AMES, B, BM, BOG, BR, CAY, CHOCO, COL, CUVC, F, HBG, HUA, JAUM, K, MEDEL, M, MO, P, RPSC, SEL, U, UGDA, VALLE, W, WRSL and WAG. The keys for determination of the taxa are dichotomical. Specimens with uncertain determination (cf.) are added to the suitable proper species. Specimens, which are not identified, are listed after decribed species. Species reported from neighbouring countries, but not found in Colombia so far, are listed without numbers. The characteristic of every species contains: latin name, abbreviation of the authors’ names, citation, type collection, synonyms, description, ecology, distribution and list of representative specimens. Citation and synonyms are written accordingly to the taxonomical norms. In case of more than one synonym, they are listed chronologically. The abbreviations of the authors’ names are followed by Brummitt and Powell (1992). The herbarium sheets are listed according to localities alphabetically, but when there was a lack of locality’s name on the sheet - in the end. The sheet’s description contains: the collector’s name with number, information about locality and habitat, the date of collecting and the acronym of herbarium. For sheets, where was more than one species on, the letters additionaly were used after dash for each taxon. The acronyms’ of herbariums are adopted from Index Herbariorum (Holmgren & al. 1992). The information from the herbarium sheets are left in original reading. Information on the labels was used to describe ecological requirements: habitat, flowering time, altitude for species. Flowering time and altitude are given only for Colombia, if available. We plan to publish ca 20 volumes of this series.

Orchids of the Guianas (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana).
Project
The present study of the orchid flora is based on the herbarium material and field expeditions to French Guiana carried by Szlachetko in 1997 and 1999. The total number of revised specimens was over 10,000 (excluding Epidendrum and Pleurothallidinae). They were either borrowed from or examined in the following institutions: AAU, AMES, B, BM, BR, CAY, COL, COAH, GOET, HBG, K, MO, NY, P, RPSC, U, US, W, WAG and Z. The keys for the determination of the taxa are dichotomous. The characteristic of every species contains the following: Latin name, abbreviation of the authors’ names, citation, synonymy, taxonomic description, ecology, distribution and the list of representative specimens. Synonyms are written accordingly to the taxonomical norms. They are listed chronologically in case of more than one synonym. The abbreviations of titles follow those in BPH (Lawrence & al. 1968), BPH/S (Bridson & Smith 1991), TL2 (Stafleu & Cowan 1976-1988) and TL2/S (Stafleu & Mennega 1992†), the abbreviations of the authors’ names follow by Brummitt and Powell (1992). The herbarium specimens are listed according to collectors’ names alphabetically, when there was a lack of collector’s name on the sheet label – it was placed in the end. The specimens without numbers are placed in the end of the list. The specimen description contains the collector’s name with number, locality, the date of collecting and the acronym of the herbarium, where the specimen is deposited. For sheets, where there was more than one species on, the letters additionally were used after dash for each taxon. The acronyms of herbaria are adopted from Index Herbariorum (Holmgren & al. 1992). The information from the herbarium sheets is left in original reading. The information on the labels was used to describe ecological requirements for particular species: habitat, flowering time and altitude above sea level. The flowering time and altitude are given for the Guianas, if available. The distribution maps were prepared with QGIS Software (http://www.qgis.org) based on the coordinates given on the herbarium labels. Maps for species known from at least four localities on the study area are included. A standard procedure of examining the herbarium material was used. Data taken from the labels were analysed. Vegetative and generative features have been studied. The vegetative characters of individual plant have been analysed. Then, the particular parts of the flower were rehydrated, dissected, measured and drawn under a binocular microscope. Then, the results were compared with the type specimen, if available, diagnosis and original illustrations. Every studied herbarium specimen has been photographed or digitalized using the scanner. The database of materials is available in the first author’s archives. Copies of all original drawings are obtainable for students upon request from the senior author. The access to a complete set of diagnoses and studied taxa full iconography has been obtained. The book is not an exhaustive study of the subject, but rather a springboard to further investigation of the orchids in this interesting area. The process of collecting the material was highly time-consuming, as each specimen was first sketched, measured, described, photographed and finally compared with the reference material. The result was a database, which enabled the most precise determination of plants. We tried to prepare an illustration of each species to facilitate the work of the prospective researches of this area. Although we endeavoured to make them on the basis of the material from the Guianas, sometimes it was impossible. Unfortunately, the quality of the material gathered from the study area sometime was not good enough for preparing analytical illustrations.
